24.24: As cold waters to a faint soul, So is good news from a far country.
24.25: As a troubled fountain, and a corrupted spring, So is a righteous man that giveth way before the wicked.
24.26: It is not good to eat much honey; So for men to search out their own glory is not glory.
24.27: Like a city broken down and without a wall, So is he whose spirit is without restraint.
24.20: If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat, And if he be thirsty, give him water to drink;
24.21: For thou wilt heap coals of fire upon his head, And the LORD will reward thee.
24.22: The north wind bringeth forth rain, And a backbiting tongue an angry countenance.
24.23: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop, Than in a house in common with a contentious woman.
24.1: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing; but the glory of kings is to search out a matter.
24.0: These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.
24.3: Take away the dross from the silver, and there cometh forth a vessel for the refiner;
24.2: The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable.
24.5: Glorify not thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men;
24.4: Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.
24.7: Go not forth hastily to strive, lest thou know not what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.
24.6: For better is it that it be said unto thee: ‘Come up hither’, than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince, whom thine eyes have seen.
24.9: Lest he that heareth it revile thee, and thine infamy turn not away.
24.8: Debate thy cause with thy neighbour, but reveal not the secret of another;
24.11: As an ear-ring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, So is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.
24.10: A word fitly spoken Is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
24.13: As vapours and wind without rain, So is he that boasteth himself of a false gift.
24.12: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, So is a faithful messenger to him that sendeth him; For he refresheth the soul of his master. .
24.15: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, Lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.
24.14: By long forbearing is a ruler persuaded, And a soft tongue breaketh the bone.
24.17: As a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow, So is a man that beareth false witness against his neighbour.
24.16: Let thy foot be seldom in thy neighbour’s house; Lest he be sated with thee, and hate thee.
24.19: As one that taketh off a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre, So is he that singeth songs to a heavy heart.
24.18: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble Is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

25.24: When he speaketh fair, Believe him not; For there are seven abominations in his heart.
25.25: Though his hatred be concealed with deceit, His wickedness shall be revealed before the congregation.
25.26: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein; And he that rolleth a stone, it shall return upon him.
25.27: A lying tongue hateth those that are crushed by it; And a flattering mouth worketh ruin.
25.20: As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; So is a contentious man to kindle strife.
25.21: The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels, And they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
25.22: Burning lips and a wicked heart Are like an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross.
25.23: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, But he layeth up deceit within him.
25.1: As the wandering sparrow, as the flying swallow, So the curse that is causeless shall come home. .
25.0: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, So honour is not seemly for a fool.
25.3: Answer not a fool according to his folly, Lest thou also be like unto him.
25.2: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, And a rod for the back of fools.
25.5: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool Cutteth off his own feet, and drinketh damage.
25.4: Answer a fool according to his folly, Lest he be wise in his own eyes.
25.7: As a small stone in a heap of stones, So is he that giveth honour to a fool.
25.6: The legs hang limp from the lame; So is a parable in the mouth of fools.
25.9: A master performeth all things; But he that stoppeth a fool is as one that stoppeth a flood.
25.8: As a thorn that cometh into the hand of a drunkard, So is a parable in the mouth of fools.
25.11: Seest thou a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope of a fool than of him.
25.10: As a dog that returneth to his vomit, So is a fool that repeateth his folly.
25.13: The door is turning upon its hinges, And the sluggard is still upon his bed.
25.12: The sluggard saith: ‘There is a lion in the way; Yea, a lion is in the streets.’
25.15: The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes Than seven men that give wise answer.
25.14: The sluggard burieth his hand in the dish; It wearieth him to bring it back to his mouth.
25.17: As a madman who casteth firebrands, Arrows, and death;
25.16: He that passeth by, and meddleth with strife not his own, Is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.
25.19: Where no wood is, the fire goeth out; And where there is no whisperer, contention ceaseth.
25.18: So is the man that deceiveth his neighbour, And saith: ‘Am not I in sport?’

26.24: When the hay is mown, and the tender grass showeth itself, And the herbs of the mountains are gathered in;
26.25: The lambs will be for thy clothing, And the goats the price for a field. .
26.26: And there will be goats’milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household; And maintenance for thy maidens.
26.20: The refining pot is for silver, and the furnace for gold, And a man is tried by his praise.
26.21: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar with a pestle among groats, Yet will not his foolishness depart from him.
26.22: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, And look well to thy herds;
26.23: For riches are not for ever; And doth the crown endure unto all generations?
26.1: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; A stranger, and not thine own lips.
26.0: Boast not thyself of to- morrow; For thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
26.3: Wrath is cruel, and anger is overwhelming; But who is able to stand before jealousy?
26.2: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; But a fool’s vexation is heavier than they both.
26.5: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; But the kisses of an enemy are importunate.
26.4: Better is open rebuke Than love that is hidden.
26.7: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, So is a man that wandereth from his place.
26.6: The full soul loatheth a honeycomb; But to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
26.9: Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; Neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity; Better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
26.8: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart; So doth the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.
26.11: A prudent man seeth the evil, and hideth himself; But the thoughtless pass on, and are punished.
26.10: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, That I may answer him that taunteth me.
26.13: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, It shall be counted a curse to him.
26.12: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger; And hold him in pledge that is surety for an alien woman.
26.15: He that would hide her hideth the wind, And the ointment of his right hand betrayeth itself.
26.14: A continual dropping in a very rainy day And a contentious woman are alike;
26.17: Whoso keepeth the fig-tree shall eat the fruit thereof; And he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.
26.16: Iron sharpeneth iron; So a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
26.19: The nether-world and Destruction are never satiated; So the eyes of man are never satiated.
26.18: As in water face answereth to face, So the heart of man to man.

27.24: He that is of a greedy spirit stirreth up strife; But he that putteth his trust in the LORD shall be abundantly gratified.
27.25: He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool; But whoso walketh wisely, he shall escape.
27.26: He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack; But he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.
27.27: When the wicked rise, men hide themselves; But when they perish, the righteous increase.
27.20: To have respect of persons is not good; For a man will transgress for a piece of bread.
27.21: He that hath an evil eye hasteneth after riches, And knoweth not that want shall come upon him.
27.22: He that rebuketh a man shall in the end find more favour Than he that flattereth with the tongue.
27.23: Whoso robbeth his father or his mother, and saith: ‘It is no transgression’, The same is the companion of a destroyer.
27.1: For the transgression of a land many are the princes thereof; But by a man of understanding and knowledge established order shall long continue.
27.0: The wicked flee when no man pursueth; But the righteous are secure as a young lion.
27.3: They that forsake the law praise the wicked; But such as keep the law contend with them.
27.2: A poor man that oppresseth the weak Is like a sweeping rain which leaveth no food.
27.5: Better is the poor that walketh in his integrity, Than he that is perverse in his ways, though he be rich.
27.4: Evil men understand not justice; But they that seek the LORD understand all things.
27.7: He that augmenteth his substance by interest and increase, Gathereth it for him that is gracious to the poor.
27.6: A wise son observeth the teaching; ut he that is a companion of gluttonous men shameth his father.
27.9: Whoso causeth the upright to go astray in an evil way, He shall fall himself into his own pit; But the whole-hearted shall inherit good.
27.8: He that turneth away his ear from hearing the law, Even his prayer is an abomination.
27.11: When the righteous exult, there is great glory; But when the wicked rise, men must be sought for.
27.10: The rich man is wise in his own eyes; But the poor that hath understanding searcheth him through.
27.13: Happy is the man that feareth alway; But he that hardeneth his heart shall fall into evil.
27.12: He that covereth his transgressions shall not prosper; But whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall obtain mercy.
27.15: The prince that lacketh understanding is also a great oppressor; But he that hateth covetousness shall prolong his days.
27.14: As a roaring lion, and a ravenous bear; So is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
27.17: Whoso walketh uprightly shall be saved; But he that is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.
27.16: A man that is laden with the blood of any person Shall hasten his steps unto the pit; none will support him.
27.19: A faithful man shall abound with blessings; But he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be unpunished.
27.18: He that tilleth his ground shall have plenty of bread; But he that followeth after vain things shall have poverty enough.

20.24: The desire of the slothful killeth him; For his hands refuse to labour.
20.25: There is that coveteth greedily all the day long; But the righteous giveth and spareth not.
20.26: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; How much more, when he bringeth it with the proceeds of wickedness?
20.27: A false witness shall perish; But the man that obeyeth shall speak unchallenged.
20.20: He that followeth after righteousness and mercy Findeth life, prosperity, and honour.
20.21: A wise man scaleth the city of the mighty, And bringeth down the stronghold wherein it trusteth.
20.22: Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue Keepeth his soul from troubles.
20.23: A proud and haughty man, scorner is his name, Even he that dealeth in overbearing pride.
20.28: A wicked man hardeneth his face; But as for the upright, he looketh well to his way.
20.29: There is no wisdom nor understanding Nor counsel against the LORD.
20.1: Every way of a man is right in his own eyes; But the LORD weigheth the hearts.
20.0: The king’s heart is in the hand of the LORD, as the watercourses: He turneth it whithersoever He will.
20.3: A haughty look, and a proud heart— The tillage of the wicked is sin.
20.2: To do righteousness and justice Is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
20.5: The getting of treasures by a lying tongue Is a vapour driven to and fro; they [that seek them] seek death.
20.4: The thoughts of the diligent tend only to plenteousness; But every one that is hasty hasteth only to want.
20.7: The way of man is froward and strange; But as for the pure, his work is right.
20.6: The violence of the wicked shall drag them away; Because they refuse to do justly.
20.9: The soul of the wicked desireth evil; His neighbour findeth no favour in his eyes.
20.8: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop, Than in a house in common with a contentious woman.
20.11: The Righteous One considereth the house of the wicked; Overthrowing the wicked to their ruin.
20.10: When the scorner is punished, the thoughtless is made wise; And when the wise is instructed, he receiveth knowledge.
20.13: A gift in secret pacifieth anger, And a present in the bosom strong wrath.
20.12: Whoso stoppeth his ears at the cry of the poor, He also shall cry himself, but shall not be answered.
20.15: The man that strayeth out of the way of understanding Shall rest in the congregation of the shades.
20.14: To do justly is joy to the righteous, But ruin to the workers of iniquity.
20.17: The wicked is a ransom for the righteous; And the faithless cometh in the stead of the upright.
20.16: He that loveth pleasure shall be a poor man; He that loveth wine and oil shall not be rich.
20.19: There is desirable treasure and oil in the dwelling of the wise; But a foolish man swalloweth it up.
20.18: It is better to dwell in a desert land, Than with a contentious and fretful woman.
20.30: The horse is prepared against the day of battle; But victory is of the LORD.

21.24: Lest thou learn his ways, And get a snare to thy soul.
21.25: Be thou not of them that strike hands, Or of them that are sureties for debts;
21.26: If thou hast not wherewith to pay, Why should he take away thy bed from under thee?
21.27: Remove not the ancient landmark, Which thy fathers have set.
21.20: That I might make thee know the certainty of the words of truth, That thou mightest bring back words of truth to them that send thee?
21.21: Rob not the weak, because he is weak, Neither crush the poor in the gate;
21.22: For the LORD will plead their cause, And despoil of life those that despoil them.
21.23: Make no friendship with a man that is given to anger; And with a wrathful man thou shalt not go;
21.28: Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; He shall not stand before mean men.
21.1: The rich and the poor meet together— The LORD is the maker of them all.
21.0: A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, And loving favour rather than silver and gold.
21.3: The reward of humility is the fear of the LORD, Even riches, and honour, and life.
21.2: A prudent man seeth the evil, and hideth himself; But the thoughtless pass on, and are punished.
21.5: Train up a child in the way he should go, And even when he is old, he will not depart from it.
21.4: Thorns and snares are in the way of the froward; He that keepeth his soul holdeth himself far from them.
21.7: He that soweth iniquity shall reap vanity; And the rod of his wrath shall fail.
21.6: The rich ruleth over the poor, And the borrower is servant to the lender.
21.9: Cast out the scorner, and contention will go out; Yea, strife and shame will cease.
21.8: He that hath a bountiful eye shall be blessed; For he giveth of his bread to the poor.
21.11: The eyes of the LORD preserve him that hath knowledge, But He overthroweth the words of the faithless man.
21.10: He that loveth pureness of heart, That hath grace in his lips, the king shall be his friend.
21.13: The mouth of strange women is a deep pit: He that is abhorred of the LORD shall fall therein.
21.12: The sluggard saith: ‘There is a lion without; I shall be slain in the streets.’
21.15: One may oppress the poor, yet will their gain increase; One may give to the rich, yet will want come.
21.14: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child; But the rod of correction shall drive it far from him.
21.17: For it is a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee; Let them be established altogether upon thy lips.
21.16: Incline thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, And apply thy heart unto my knowledge.
21.19: Have not I written unto thee excellent things Of counsels and knowledge;
21.18: That thy trust may be in the LORD, I have made them known to thee this day, even to thee.

22.24: Let thy father and thy mother be glad, and let her that bore thee rejoice.
22.25: My son, give me thy heart, and let thine eyes observe my ways. .
22.26: For a harlot is a deep ditch; and an alien woman is a narrow pit.
22.27: She also lieth in wait as a robber, and increaseth the faithless among men.
22.20: For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty; And drowsiness shall clothe a man with rags.
22.21: Hearken unto thy father that begot thee, And despise not thy mother when she is old.
22.22: Buy the truth, and sell it not; also wisdom, and instruction, and understanding.
22.23: The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice; and he that begetteth a wise child will have joy of him.
22.28: Who crieth: ‘Woe’? who: ‘Alas’? Who hath contentions? who hath raving? Who hath wounds without cause? Who hath redness of eyes?
22.29: They that tarry long at the wine; They that go to try mixed wine.
22.1: And put a knife to thy throat, if thou be a man given to appetite.
22.0: When thou sittest to eat with a ruler, consider well him that is before thee;
22.3: Weary not thyself to be rich; Cease from thine own wisdom. .
22.2: Be not desirous of his dainties; seeing they are deceitful food.
22.5: Eat thou not the bread of him that hath an evil eye, Neither desire thou his dainties;
22.4: Wilt thou set thine eyes upon it? it is gone; For riches certainly make themselves wings, Like an eagle that flieth toward heaven.
22.7: The morsel which thou hast eaten shalt thou vomit up, And lose thy sweet words.
22.6: For as one that hath reckoned within himself, so is he: ‘Eat and drink’, saith he to thee; But his heart is not with thee.
22.9: Remove not the ancient landmark; and enter not into the fields of the fatherless;
22.8: Speak not in the ears of a fool; for he will despise the wisdom of thy words.
22.11: Apply thy heart unto instruction, And thine ears to the words of knowledge.
22.10: For their Redeemer is strong; He will plead their cause with thee.
22.13: Thou beatest him with the rod, And wilt deliver his soul from the nether-world.
22.12: Withhold not correction from the child; For though thou beat him with the rod, he will not die.
22.15: Yea, my reins will rejoice, When thy lips speak right things.
22.14: My son, if thy heart be wise, My heart will be glad, even mine;
22.17: For surely there is a future; And thy hope shall not be cut off.
22.16: Let not thy heart envy sinners, But be in the fear of the LORD all the day;
22.19: Be not among winebibbers; Among gluttonous eaters of flesh;
22.18: Hear thou, my son, and be wise, And guide thy heart in the way.
22.31: At the last it biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like a basilisk.
22.30: Look not thou upon the wine when it is red, when it giveth its colour in the cup, When it glideth down smoothly;
22.34: ’They have struck me, and I felt it not, they have beaten me, and I knew it not; when shall I awake? I will seek it yet again.’
22.33: Yea, thou shalt be as he that lieth down in the midst of the sea, or as he that lieth upon the top of a mast.
22.32: Thine eyes shall behold strange things, and thy heart shall utter confused things.

23.24: But to them that decide justly shall be delight, And a good blessing shall come upon them.
23.25: He kisseth the lips That giveth a right answer.
23.26: Prepare thy work without, And make it fit for thyself in the field; And afterwards build thy house.
23.27: Be not a witness against thy neighbour without cause; And deceive not with thy lips.
23.20: My son, fear thou the LORD and the king, And meddle not with them that are given to change;
23.21: For their calamity shall rise suddenly; And who knoweth the ruin from them both?
23.22: These also are sayings of the wise. To have respect of persons in judgment is not good.
23.23: He that saith unto the wicked: ‘Thou art righteous’, Peoples shall curse him, nations shall execrate him;
23.28: Say not: ‘I will do so to him as he hath done to me; I will render to the man according to his work.’
23.29: I went by the field of the slothful, And by the vineyard of the man void of understanding;
23.1: For their heart studieth destruction, And their lips talk of mischief.
23.0: Be not thou envious of evil men, Neither desire to be with them.
23.3: And by knowledge are the chambers filled With all precious and pleasant riches.
23.2: Through wisdom is a house builded; And by understanding it is established;
23.5: For with wise advice thou shalt make thy war; And in the multitude of counsellors there is safety.
23.4: A wise man is strong; Yea, a man of knowledge increaseth strength.
23.7: He that deviseth to do evil, Men shall call him a mischievous person.
23.6: Wisdom is as unattainable to a fool as corals; He openeth not his mouth in the gate.
23.9: If thou faint in the day of adversity, Thy strength is small indeed.
23.8: The thought of foolishness is sin; And the scorner is an abomination to men.
23.11: If thou sayest: ‘Behold, we knew not this’, Doth not He that weigheth the hearts consider it? And He that keepeth thy soul, doth not He know it? And shall not He render to every man according to his works?
23.10: Deliver them that are drawn unto death; And those that are ready to be slain wilt thou forbear to rescue?
23.13: So know thou wisdom to be unto thy soul; If thou hast found it, then shall there be a future, And thy hope shall not be cut off.
23.12: My son, eat thou honey, for it is good, And the honeycomb is sweet to thy taste;
23.15: For a righteous man falleth seven times, and riseth up again, But the wicked stumble under adversity.
23.14: Lie not in wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous, Spoil not his resting-place;
23.17: Lest the LORD see it, and it displease Him, And He turn away His wrath from him.
23.16: Rejoice not when thine enemy falleth, And let not thy heart be glad when he stumbleth;
23.19: For there will be no future to the evil man, The lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
23.18: Fret not thyself because of evildoers, Neither be thou envious at the wicked;
23.31: Then I beheld, and considered well; I saw, and received instruction.
23.30: And, lo, it was all grown over with thistles, The face thereof was covered with nettles, And the stone wall thereof was broken down.
23.33: So shall thy poverty come as a runner, And thy want as an armed man.
23.32: ’Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, A little folding of the hands to sleep’—

28.24: The fear of man bringeth a snare; but whoso putteth his trust in the LORD shall be set up on high.
28.25: Many seek the ruler’s favour; but a man’s judgment cometh from the LORD.
28.26: An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous; and he that is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked.
28.20: He that delicately bringeth up his servant from a child Shall have him become master at the last.
28.21: An angry man stirreth up strife, And a wrathful man aboundeth in transgression.
28.22: A man’s pride shall bring him low; but he that is of a lowly spirit shall attain to honour.
28.23: Whoso is partner with a thief hateth his own soul: He heareth the adjuration and uttereth nothing.
28.1: When the righteous are increased, the people rejoice; but when the wicked beareth rule, the people sigh.
28.0: He that being often reproved hardeneth his neck Shall suddenly be broken, and that without remedy.
28.3: The king by justice establisheth the land; but he that exacteth gifts overthroweth it.
28.2: Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father; but he that keepeth company with harlots wasteth his substance.
28.5: In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare; but the righteous doth sing and rejoice.
28.4: A man that flattereth his neighbour spreadeth a net for his steps.
28.7: Scornful men set a city in a blaze; But wise men turn away wrath.
28.6: The righteous taketh knowledge of the cause of the poor; the wicked understandeth not knowledge.
28.9: The men of blood hate him that is sincere; And as for the upright, they seek his life.
28.8: If a wise man contendeth with a foolish man, Whether he be angry or laugh, there will be no rest.
28.11: If a ruler hearkeneth to falsehood, All his servants are wicked.
28.10: A fool spendeth all his spirit; But a wise man stilleth it within him.
28.13: The king that faithfully judgeth the poor, His throne shall be established for ever.
28.12: The poor man and the oppressor meet together; The LORD giveth light to the eyes of them both.
28.15: When the wicked are increased, transgression increaseth; But the righteous shall gaze upon their fall.
28.14: The rod and reproof give wisdom; But a child left to himself causeth shame to his mother.
28.17: Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; But he that keepeth the law, happy is he.
28.16: Correct thy son, and he will give thee rest; Yea, he will give delight unto thy soul.
28.19: Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
28.18: A servant will not be corrected by words; For though he understand, there will be no response.

29.24: The ants are a people not strong, Yet they provide their food in the summer;
29.25: The rock-badgers are but a feeble folk, Yet make they their houses in the crags;
29.26: The locusts have no king, Yet go they forth all of them by bands;
29.27: The spider thou canst take with the hands, Yet is she in kings’palaces.
29.20: For three things the earth doth quake, And for four it cannot endure:
29.21: For a servant when he reigneth; And a churl when he is filled with food;
29.22: For an odious woman when she is married; And a handmaid that is heir to her mistress.
29.23: There are four things which are little upon the earth, But they are exceeding wise:
29.28: There are three things which are stately in their march, Yea, four which are stately in going:
29.29: The lion, which is mightiest among beasts, And turneth not away for any;
29.1: Surely I am brutish, unlike a man, And have not the understanding of a man;
29.0: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh; the burden. The man saith unto Ithiel, unto Ithiel and Ucal:
29.3: Who hath ascended up into heaven, and descended? Who hath gathered the wind in his fists? Who hath bound the waters in his garment? Who hath established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is his son’s name, if thou knowest?
29.2: And I have not learned wisdom, That I should have the knowledge of the Holy One.
29.5: Add thou not unto His words, Lest He reprove thee, and thou be found a liar.
29.4: Every word of God is tried; He is a shield unto them that take refuge in Him.
29.7: Remove far from me falsehood and lies; Give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with mine allotted bread;
29.6: Two things have I asked of Thee; Deny me them not before I die:
29.9: Slander not a servant unto his master, Lest he curse thee, and thou be found guilty.
29.8: Lest I be full, and deny, and say: ‘Who is the LORD?’ Or lest I be poor, and steal, And profane the name of my God.
29.11: There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, And yet are not washed from their filthiness.
29.10: There is a generation that curse their father, And do not bless their mother.
29.13: There is a generation whose teeth are as swords, and their great teeth as knives, To devour the poor from off the earth, and the needy from among men.
29.12: There is a generation, Oh how lofty are their eyes! And their eyelids are lifted up.
29.15: The grave; and the barren womb; The earth that is not satisfied with water; And the fire that saith not: ‘Enough.’
29.14: The horseleech hath two daughters: ‘Give, give.’ There are three things that are never satisfied, Yea, four that say not: ‘Enough’:
29.17: There are three things which are too wonderful for me, Yea, four which I know not:

29.18: The way of an eagle in the air; The way of a serpent upon a rock; The way of a ship in the midst of the sea; And the way of a man with a young woman.
29.31: If thou hast done foolishly in lifting up thyself, Or if thou hast planned devices, lay thy hand upon thy mouth.
29.30: The greyhound; the he-goat also; And the king, against whom there is no rising up.
29.32: For the churning of milk bringeth forth curd, And the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood; So the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife.

1.20: For the upright shall dwell in the land, And the whole-hearted shall remain in it.

1.1: So that thou make thine ear attend unto wisdom, And thy heart incline to discernment;

1.5: For the LORD giveth wisdom, Out of His mouth cometh knowledge and discernment;
1.4: Then shalt thou understand the fear of the LORD, And find the knowledge of God.
1.7: That He may guard the paths of justice, And preserve the way of His godly ones. .
1.6: He layeth up sound wisdom for the upright, He is a shield to them that walk in integrity;
1.9: For wisdom shall enter into thy heart, And knowledge shall be pleasant unto thy soul;
1.8: Then shalt thou understand righteousness and justice, And equity, yea, every good path.
1.11: To deliver thee from the way of evil, From the men that speak froward things;
1.10: Discretion shall watch over thee, Discernment shall guard thee;
1.13: Who rejoice to do evil, And delight in the frowardness of evil;
1.12: Who leave the paths of uprightness, To walk in the ways of darkness;
1.15: To deliver thee from the strange woman, Even from the alien woman that maketh smooth her words;
1.14: Who are crooked in their ways, And perverse in their paths;
1.17: For her house sinketh down unto death, And her paths unto the shades;
1.16: That forsaketh the lord of her youth, And forgetteth the covenant of her God.

0.24: But ye have set at nought all my counsel, and would none of my reproof;

0.20: She calleth at the head of the noisy streets, at the entrances of the gates, in the city, she uttereth her words:
0.21: ’How long, ye thoughtless, will ye love thoughtlessness? And how long will scorners delight them in scorning, And fools hate knowledge?
0.22: Turn you at my reproof; behold, I will pour out my spirit unto you, I will make known my words unto you.
0.23: Because I have called, and ye refused, I have stretched out my hand, and no man attended,
0.28: For that they hated knowledge, and did not choose the fear of the LORD;
0.29: They would none of my counsel, they despised all my reproof.
0.1: To know wisdom and instruction; To comprehend the words of understanding;
0.0: The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel;
0.3: To give prudence to the simple, To the young man knowledge and discretion;
0.2: To receive the discipline of wisdom, Justice, and right, and equity;
0.5: To understand a proverb, and a figure; The words of the wise, and their dark sayings.
0.4: That the wise man may hear, and increase in learning, And the man of understanding may attain unto wise counsels;
0.7: Hear, my son, the instruction of thy father, And forsake not the teaching of thy mother;
0.6: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; But the foolish despise wisdom and discipline.
0.9: My son, if sinners entice thee, Consent thou not.
0.8: For they shall be a chaplet of grace unto thy head, And chains about thy neck.
0.11: Let us swallow them up alive as the grave, and whole, as those that go down into the pit;
0.10: If they say: ‘Come with us, Let us lie in wait for blood, Let us lurk for the innocent without cause;
0.13: Cast in thy lot among us; Let us all have one purse’—
0.12: We shall find all precious substance, We shall fill our houses with spoil;
0.15: For their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed blood.
0.14: My son, walk not thou in the way with them, restrain thy foot from their path;
0.17: And these lie in wait for their own blood, they lurk for their own lives.
0.16: For in vain the net is spread in the eyes of any bird;

0.31: For the waywardness of the thoughtless shall slay them, and the confidence of fools shall destroy them.

3.24: Let thine eyes look right on, And let thine eyelids look straight before thee.
3.25: Make plain the path of thy feet, And let all thy ways be established.
3.26: Turn not to the right hand nor to the left; Remove thy foot from evil.
3.20: Let them not depart from thine eyes; Keep them in the midst of thy heart.
3.21: For they are life unto those that find them, And health to all their flesh.
3.22: Above all that thou guardest keep thy heart; For out of it are the issues of life.
3.23: Put away from thee a froward mouth, And perverse lips put far from thee.
3.1: For I give you a good taking; Forsake ye not my teaching.
3.0: Hear, ye children, the instruction of a father, And attend to know understanding.
3.3: And he taught me, and said unto me: ‘Let thy heart hold fast my words, Keep my commandments, and live;
3.2: For I was a son unto my father, Tender and an only one in front of my mother.
3.5: Forsake her not, and she will preserve thee; Love her, and she will keep thee.
3.4: Get wisdom, get understanding; Forget not, neither decline from the words of my mouth;
3.7: Extol her, and she will exalt thee; She will bring thee to honour, when thou dost embrace her.
3.6: The beginning of wisdom is: Get wisdom; Yea, with all thy getting get understanding.
3.9: Hear, O my son, and receive my sayings; And the years of thy life shall be many.
3.8: She will give to thy head a chaplet of grace; A crown of glory will she bestow on thee.’
3.11: When thou goest, thy step shall not be straitened; And if thou runnest, thou shalt not stumble.
3.10: I have taught thee in the way of wisdom; I have led thee in paths of uprightness.
3.13: Enter not into the path of the wicked, And walk not in the way of evil men.
3.12: Take fast hold of instruction, let her not go; Keep her, for she is thy life.
3.15: For they sleep not, except they have done evil; And their sleep is taken away, unless they cause some to fall.
3.14: Avoid it, pass not by it; Turn from it, and pass on.
3.17: But the path of the righteous is as the light of dawn, That shineth more and more unto the perfect day.
3.16: For they eat the bread of wickedness, And drink the wine of violence.
3.19: My son, attend to my words; Incline thine ear unto my sayings.
3.18: The way of the wicked is as darkness; They know not at what they stumble.

2.24: Be not afraid of sudden terror, Neither of the destruction of the wicked, when it cometh;

2.26: Withhold not good from him to whom it is due, When it is in the power of thy hand to do it.
2.27: Say not unto thy neighbour: ‘Go, and come again, And to-morrow I will give’; when thou hast it by thee.

2.21: So shall they be life unto thy soul, And grace to thy neck.
2.22: Then shalt thou walk in thy way securely, And thou shalt not dash thy foot.
2.23: When thou liest down, thou shalt not be afraid; Yea, thou shalt lie down, and thy sleep shall be sweet.
2.28: Devise not evil against thy neighbour, Seeing he dwelleth securely by thee.
2.29: Strive not with a man without cause, If he have done thee no harm.
2.1: For length of days, and years of life, And peace, will they add to thee.
2.0: My son, forget not my teaching; But let thy heart keep my commandments;

2.2: Let not kindness and truth forsake thee; Bind them about thy neck, write them upon the table of thy heart;
2.5: In all thy ways acknowledge Him, And He will direct thy paths.
2.4: Trust in the LORD with all thy heart, And lean not upon thine own understanding.
2.7: It shall be health to thy navel, And marrow to thy bones.
2.6: Be not wise in thine own eyes; Fear the LORD, and depart from evil;
2.9: So shall thy barns be filled with plenty, And thy vats shall overflow with new wine.
2.8: Honour the LORD with thy substance, And with the first-fruits of all thine increase;
2.11: For whom the LORD loveth He correcteth, Even as a father the son in whom he delighteth.

2.13: For the merchandise of it is better than the merchandise of silver, And the gain thereof than fine gold.

2.15: Length of days is in her right hand; In her left hand are riches and honour.

2.17: She is a tree of life to them that lay hold upon her, And happy is every one that holdest her fast.
2.16: Her ways are ways of pleasantness, And all her paths are peace.
2.19: By His knowledge the depths were broken up, And the skies drop down the dew.

2.31: For the perverse is an abomination to the LORD; But His counsel is with the upright.

7.24: Before the mountains were settled, Before the hills was I brought forth;
7.25: While as yet He had not made the earth, nor the fields, Nor the beginning of the dust of the world.
7.26: When He established the heavens, I was there; When He set a circle upon the face of the deep,
7.27: When He made firm the skies above, When the fountains of the deep showed their might,
7.20: That I may cause those that love me to inherit substance, And that I may fill their treasuries.
7.21: The LORD made me as the beginning of His way, The first of His works of old.
7.22: I was set up from everlasting, from the beginning, Or ever the earth was.
7.23: When there were no depths, I was brought forth; When there were no fountains abounding with water.
7.28: When He gave to the sea His decree, That the waters should not transgress His commandment, When He appointed the foundations of the earth;
7.29: Then I was by Him, as a nursling; And I was daily all delight, Playing always before Him,
7.1: In the top of high places by the way, Where the paths meet, she standeth;
7.0: Doth not wisdom call, And understanding put forth her voice?
7.3: ’Unto you, O men, I call, And my voice is to the sons of men.
7.2: Beside the gates, at the entry of the city, At the coming in at the doors, she crieth aloud:
7.5: Hear, for I will speak excellent things, And the opening of my lips shall be right things.
7.4: O ye thoughtless, understand prudence, And, ye fools, be ye of an understanding heart.
7.7: All the words of my mouth are in righteousness, There is nothing perverse or crooked in them.
7.6: For my mouth shall utter truth, And wickedness is an abomination to my lips.
7.9: Receive my instruction, and not silver, And knowledge rather than choice gold.
7.8: They are all plain to him that understandeth, And right to them that find knowledge.
7.11: I wisdom dwell with prudence, And find out knowledge of devices.
7.10: For wisdom is better than rubies, And all things desirable are not to be compared unto her.
7.13: Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom; I am understanding, power is mine.
7.12: The fear of the LORD is to hate evil; Pride, and arrogancy, and the evil way, And the froward mouth, do I hate.
7.15: By me princes rule, And nobles, even all the judges of the earth.
7.14: By me kings reign, And princes decree justice.
7.17: Riches and honour are with me; Yea, enduring riches and righteousness.
7.16: I love them that love me, And those that seek me earnestly shall find me.
7.19: I walk in the way of righteousness, In the midst of the paths of justice;
7.18: My fruit is better than gold, yea, than fine gold; And my produce than choice silver.
7.31: Now therefore, ye children, hearken unto me; For happy are they that keep my ways.
7.30: Playing in His habitable earth, And my delights are with the sons of men.
7.35: But he that misseth me wrongeth his own soul; All they that hate me love death.’
7.34: For whoso findeth me findeth life, And obtaineth favour of the LORD.
7.33: Happy is the man that hearkeneth to me, Watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.
7.32: Hear instruction, and be wise, And refuse it not.

6.24: Let not thy heart decline to her ways, Go not astray in her paths.

6.26: Her house is the way to the nether-world, Going down to the chambers of death.
6.20: With her much fair speech she causeth him to yield, With the blandishment of her lips she enticeth him away.

6.22: Till an arrow strike through his liver; As a bird hasteneth to the snare— And knoweth not that it is at the cost of his life.

6.1: Keep my commandments and live, And my teaching as the apple of thine eye.
6.0: My son, keep my words, And lay up my commandments with thee.
6.3: Say unto wisdom: ‘Thou art my sister’, And call understanding thy kinswoman;
6.2: Bind them upon thy fingers, Write them upon the table of thy heart.
6.5: For at the window of my house I looked forth through my lattice;
6.4: That they may keep thee from the strange woman, From the alien woman that maketh smooth her words.
6.7: Passing through the street near her corner, And he went the way to her house;
6.6: And I beheld among the thoughtless ones, I discerned among the youths, A young man void of understanding,
6.9: And, behold, there met him a woman With the attire of a harlot, and wily of heart.
6.8: In the twilight, in the evening of the day, In the blackness of night and the darkness.
6.11: Now she is in the streets, now in the broad places, And lieth in wait at every corner.
6.10: She is riotous and rebellious, Her feet abide not in her house;
6.13: ’Sacrifices of peace-offerings were due from me; This day have I paid my vows.
6.12: So she caught him, and kissed him, And with an impudent face she said unto him:
6.15: I have decked my couch with coverlets, With striped cloths of the yarn of Egypt.

6.17: Come, let us take our fill of love until the morning; Let us solace ourselves with loves.
6.16: I have perfumed my bed With myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

6.18: For my husband is not at home, He is gone a long journey;

9.24: When the whirlwind passeth, the wicked is no more; But the righteous is an everlasting foundation.
9.25: As vinegar to the teeth, and as smoke to the eyes, So is the sluggard to them that send him.
9.26: The fear of the LORD prolongeth days; But the years of the wicked shall be shortened.
9.27: The hope of the righteous is gladness; But the expectation of the wicked shall perish.
9.20: The lips of the righteous feed many; But the foolish die for want of understanding. .
9.21: The blessing of the LORD, it maketh rich, And toil addeth nothing thereto.
9.22: It is as sport to a fool to do wickedness, And so is wisdom to a man of discernment.
9.23: The fear of the wicked, it shall come upon him; And the desire of the righteous shall be granted.
9.28: The way of the LORD is a stronghold to the upright, But ruin to the workers of iniquity.
9.29: The righteous shall never be moved; But the wicked shall not inhabit the land.
9.1: Treasures of wickedness profit nothing; but righteousness delivereth from death.
9.0: The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son maketh a glad father; but a foolish son is the grief of his mother.
9.3: He becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand; but the hand of the diligent maketh rich.
9.2: The LORD will not suffer the soul of the righteous to famish; but He thrusteth away the desire of the wicked.
9.5: Blessings are upon the head of the righteous; but the mouth of the wicked concealeth violence.
9.4: A wise son gathereth in summer; but a son that doeth shamefully sleepeth in harvest.
9.7: The wise in heart will receive commandments; but a prating fool shall fall.
9.6: The memory of the righteous shall be for a blessing; but the name of the wicked shall rot.
9.9: He that winketh with the eye causeth sorrow; and a prating fool shall fall.
9.8: He that walketh uprightly walketh securely; but he that perverteth his ways shall be found out.
9.11: Hatred stirreth up strifes; but love covereth all transgressions.
9.10: The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life; but the mouth of the wicked concealeth violence.
9.13: Wise men lay up knowledge; but the mouth of the foolish is an imminent ruin.
9.12: In the lips of him that hath discernment wisdom is found; but a rod is for the back of him that is void of understanding.
9.15: The wages of the righteous is life; The increase of the wicked is sin.
9.14: The rich man’s wealth is his strong city; the ruin of the poor is their poverty.
9.17: He that hideth hatred is of lying lips; And he that uttereth a slander is a fool.
9.16: He is in the way of life that heedeth instruction; But he that forsaketh reproof erreth.
9.19: The tongue of the righteous is as choice silver; The heart of the wicked is little worth.
9.18: In the multitude of words there wanteth not transgression; But he that refraineth his lips is wise.
9.31: The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable; But the mouth of the wicked is all frowardness.
9.30: The mouth of the righteous buddeth with wisdom; But the froward tongue shall be cut off.

8.11: If thou art wise, thou art wise for thyself; And if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it.’

11.24: Care in the heart of a man boweth it down; But a good word maketh it glad.

11.20: There shall no mischief befall the righteous; But the wicked are filled with evil.
11.21: Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD; But they that deal truly are His delight. .
11.22: A prudent man concealeth knowledge; But the heart of fools proclaimeth foolishness.
11.23: The hand of the diligent shall bear rule; But the slothful shall be under tribute.
11.1: A good man shall obtain favour of the LORD; But a man of wicked devices will He condemn.
11.0: Whoso loveth knowledge loveth correction; But he that is brutish hateth reproof.
11.3: A virtuous woman is a crown to her husband; But she that doeth shamefully is as rottenness in his bones.
11.2: A man shall not be established by wickedness; But the root of the righteous shall never be moved.
11.5: The words of the wicked are to lie in wait for blood; But the mouth of the upright shall deliver them. .
11.4: The thoughts of the righteous are right; But the counsels of the wicked are deceit.
11.7: A man shall be commended according to his intelligence; But he that is of a distorted understanding shall be despised.
11.6: The wicked are overthrown, and are not; But the house of the righteous shall stand.
11.9: A righteous man regardeth the life of his beast; But the tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
11.8: Better is he that is lightly esteemed, and hath a servant, Than he that playeth the man of rank, and lacketh bread.
11.11: The wicked desireth the prey of evil men; But the root of the righteous yieldeth fruit.
11.10: He that tilleth his ground shall have plenty of bread; But he that followeth after vain things is void of understanding.
11.13: A man shall be satisfied with good by the fruit of his mouth, And the doings of a man’s hands shall be rendered unto him.
11.12: In the transgression of the lips is a snare to the evil man; But the righteous cometh out of trouble.
11.15: A fool’s vexation is presently known; But a prudent man concealeth shame.
11.14: The way of a fool is straight in his own eyes; But he that is wise hearkeneth unto counsel.
11.17: There is that speaketh like the piercings of a sword; But the tongue of the wise is health.
11.16: He that breatheth forth truth uttereth righteousness; But a false witness deceit.
11.19: Deceit is in the heart of them that devise evil; But to the counsellors of peace is joy.
11.18: The lip of truth shall be established for ever; But a lying tongue is but for a moment.

10.24: The beneficent soul shall be made rich, and he that satisfieth abundantly shall be satisfied also himself.
10.25: He that withholdeth corn, the people shall curse him; But blessing shall be upon the head of him that selleth it.
10.26: He that diligently seeketh good seeketh favour; But he that searcheth for evil, it shall come unto him.
10.27: He that trusteth in his riches shall fall; But the righteous shall flourish as foliage.
10.20: My hand upon it! the evil man shall not be unpunished; But the seed of the righteous shall escape. .
10.21: As a ring of gold in a swine’s snout, so is a fair woman that turneth aside from discretion.
10.22: The desire of the righteous is only good; But the expectation of the wicked is wrath.
10.23: There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth; And there is that withholdeth more than is meet, but it tendeth only to want.
10.28: He that troubleth his own house shall inherit the wind; And the foolish shall be servant to the wise of heart.
10.29: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life; And he that is wise winneth souls.
10.1: When pride cometh, then cometh shame; But with the lowly is wisdom.
10.0: A false balance is an abomination to the LORD; But a perfect weight is His delight.
10.3: Riches profit not in the day of wrath; But righteousness delivereth from death.
10.2: The integrity of the upright shall guide them; But the perverseness of the faithless shall destroy them.
10.5: The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them; But the faithless shall be trapped in their own crafty device.
10.4: The righteousness of the sincere shall make straight his way; But the wicked shall fall by his own wickedness. .
10.7: The righteous is delivered out of trouble, And the wicked cometh in his stead.
10.6: When a wicked man dieth, his expectation shall perish, And the hope of strength perisheth.
10.9: When it goeth well with the righteous, the city rejoiceth; And when the wicked perish, there is joy.
10.8: With his mouth the impious man destroyeth his neighbour; But through knowledge shall the righteous be delivered.
10.11: He that despiseth his neighbour lacketh understanding; But a man of discernment holdeth his peace.
10.10: By the blessing of the upright a city is exalted; But it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.
10.13: Where no wise direction is, a people falleth; But in the multitude of counsellors there is safety.
10.12: He that goeth about as a talebearer revealeth secrets; But he that is of a faithful spirit concealeth a matter.
10.15: A gracious woman obtaineth honour; And strong men obtain riches.
10.14: He that is surety for a stranger shall smart for it; But he that hateth them that strike hands is secure.
10.17: The wicked earneth deceitful wages; But he that soweth righteousness hath a sure reward.
10.16: The merciful man doeth good to his own soul; But he that is cruel troubleth his own flesh.
10.19: They that are perverse in heart are an abomination to the LORD; But such as are upright in their way are His delight.
10.18: Stedfast righteousness tendeth to life; But he that pursueth evil pursueth it to his own death.
10.30: Behold, the righteous shall be requited in the earth; How much more the wicked and the sinner!

13.24: A true witness delivereth souls; But he that breatheth forth lies is all deceit.
13.25: In the fear of the LORD a man hath strong confidence; And his children shall have a place of refuge.
13.26: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death.
13.27: In the multitude of people is the king’s glory; But in the want of people is the ruin of the prince.
13.20: He that despiseth his neighbour sinneth; But he that is gracious unto the humble, happy is he.
13.21: Shall they not go astray that devise evil? But mercy and truth shall be for them that devise good.
13.22: In all labour there is profit; But the talk of the lips tendeth only to penury.
13.23: The crown of the wise is their riches; But the folly of fools remaineth folly.
13.28: He that is slow to anger is of great understanding; But he that is hasty of spirit exalteth folly.
13.29: A tranquil heart is the life of the flesh; But envy is the rottenness of the bones.
13.1: He that walketh in his uprightness feareth the LORD; But he that is perverse in his ways despiseth Him.
13.0: Every wise woman buildeth her house; But the foolish plucketh it down with her hands.
13.3: Where no oxen are, the crib is clean; But much increase is by the strength of the ox.
13.2: In the mouth of the foolish is a rod of pride; But the lips of the wise shall preserve them. .
13.5: A scorner seeketh wisdom, and findeth it not; But knowledge is easy unto him that hath discernment.
13.4: A faithful witness will not lie; But a false witness breatheth forth lies.
13.7: The wisdom of the prudent is to look well to his way; But the folly of fools is deceit.
13.6: Go from the presence of a foolish man, for thou wilt not perceive the lips of knowledge.
13.9: The heart knoweth its own bitterness; And with its joy no stranger can intermeddle.
13.8: Amends pleadeth for fools; But among the upright there is good will.
13.11: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, But the end thereof are the ways of death.
13.10: The house of the wicked shall be overthrown; But the tent of the upright shall flourish.
13.13: The dissembler in heart shall have his fill from his own ways; And a good man shall be satisfied from himself.
13.12: Even in laughter the heart acheth; And the end of mirth is heaviness.
13.15: A wise man feareth, and departeth from evil; But the fool behaveth overbearingly, and is confident.
13.14: The thoughtless believeth every word; But the prudent man looketh well to his going.
13.17: The thoughtless come into possession of folly; But the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
13.16: He that is soon angry dealeth foolishly; And a man of wicked devices is hated.
13.19: The poor is hated even of his own neighbour; But the rich hath many friends. .
13.18: The evil bow before the good, And the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
13.31: The wicked is thrust down in his misfortune; But the righteous, even when he is brought to death, hath hope.
13.30: He that oppresseth the poor blasphemeth his Maker; But he that is gracious unto the needy honoureth Him.
13.34: The king’s favour is toward a servant that dealeth wisely; But his wrath striketh him that dealeth shamefully.
13.33: Righteousness exalteth a nation; But sin is a reproach to any people.
13.32: In the heart of him that hath discernment wisdom resteth; But in the inward part of fools it maketh itself known.

12.24: The righteous eateth to the satisfying of his desire; But the belly of the wicked shall want.
12.20: Evil pursueth sinners; But to the righteous good shall be repaid.
12.21: A good man leaveth an inheritance to his children’s children; And the wealth of the sinner is laid up for the righteous.
12.22: Much food is in the tillage of the poor; But there is that is swept away by want of righteousness.
12.23: He that spareth his rod hateth his son; But he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes.
12.1: A man shall eat good from the fruit of his mouth; But the desire of the faithless is violence.
12.0: A wise son is instructed of his father; But a scorner heareth not rebuke.
12.3: The soul of the sluggard desireth, and hath nothing; But the soul of the diligent shall be abundantly gratified.
12.2: He that guardeth his mouth keepeth his life; But for him that openeth wide his lips there shall be ruin.
12.5: Righteousness guardeth him that is upright in the way; But wickedness overthroweth the sinner.
12.4: A righteous man hateth lying; But a wicked man behaveth vilely and shamefully.
12.7: The ransom of a man’s life are his riches; But the poor heareth no threatening.
12.6: There is that pretendeth himself rich, yet hath nothing; There is that pretendeth himself poor, yet hath great wealth.
12.9: By pride cometh only contention; But with the well-advised is wisdom.
12.8: The light of the righteous rejoiceth; But the lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
12.11: Hope deferred maketh the heart sick; But desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
12.10: Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished; But he that gathereth little by little shall increase. .
12.13: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, To depart from the snares of death.
12.12: Whoso despiseth the word shall suffer thereby; But he that feareth the commandment shall be rewarded.
12.15: Every prudent man dealeth with forethought; But a fool unfoldeth folly.
12.14: Good understanding giveth grace; But the way of the faithless is harsh.
12.17: Poverty and shame shall be to him that refuseth instruction; But he that regardeth reproof shall be honoured.
12.16: A wicked messenger falleth into evil; But a faithful ambassador is health.
12.19: He that walketh with wise men shall be wise; But the companion of fools shall smart for it.
12.18: The desire accomplished is sweet to the soul; And it is an abomination to fools to depart from evil.

15.24: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, But the end thereof are the ways of death.
15.25: The hunger of the labouring man laboureth for him; For his mouth compelleth him.
15.26: An ungodly man diggeth up evil, And in his lips there is as a burning fire.
15.27: A froward man soweth strife; And a whisperer separateth familiar friends.
15.20: The wise in heart is called a man of discernment; And the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
15.21: Understanding is a fountain of life unto him that hath it; But folly is the chastisement of fools.
15.22: The heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, And addeth learning to his lips.
15.23: Pleasant words are as a honeycomb, Sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
15.28: A man of violence enticeth his neighbour, And leadeth him into a way that is not good.
15.29: He shutteth his eyes, it is to devise froward things; He that biteth his lips bringeth evil to pass.
15.1: All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes; But the LORD weigheth the spirits.
15.0: The preparations of the heart are man’s, But the answer of the tongue is from the LORD.
15.3: The LORD hath made every things for His own purpose, Yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
15.2: Commit thy works unto the LORD, And thy thoughts shall be established.
15.5: By mercy and truth iniquity is expiated; And by the fear of the LORD men depart from evil.
15.4: Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD; My hand upon it! he shall not be unpunished.
15.7: Better is a little with righteousness Than great revenues with injustice.
15.6: When a man’s ways please the LORD, He maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.
15.9: A divine sentence is in the lips of the king; His mouth trespasseth not in judgment.
15.8: A man’s heart deviseth his way; But the LORD directeth his steps.
15.11: It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness; For the throne is established by righteousness.
15.10: A just balance and scales are the LORD’S; All the weights of the bag are His work.
15.13: The wrath of a king is as messengers of death; But a wise man will pacify it.
15.12: Righteous lips are the delight of kings; And they love him that speaketh right.
15.15: How much better is it to get wisdom than gold! Yea, to get understanding is rather to be chosen than silver.
15.14: In the light of the king’s countenance is life; And his favour is as a cloud of the latter rain.
15.17: Pride goeth before destruction, And a haughty spirit before a fall.
15.16: The highway of the upright is to depart from evil; He that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
15.19: He that giveth heed unto the word shall find good; And whoso trusteth in the LORD, happy is he.
15.18: Better it is to be of a lowly spirit with the humble, Than to divide the spoil with the proud.
15.31: He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; And he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.
15.30: The hoary head is a crown of glory, It is found in the way of righteousness.
15.32: The lot is cast into the lap; But the whole disposing thereof is of the LORD.

14.24: The LORD will pluck up the house of the proud; But He will establish the border of the widow.
14.25: The thoughts of wickedness are an abomination to the LORD; But words of pleasantness are pure.
14.26: He that is greedy of gain troubleth his own house; But he that hateth gifts shall live.
14.27: The heart of the righteous studieth to answer; But the mouth of the wicked poureth out evil things.
14.20: Folly is joy to him that lacketh understanding; But a man of discernment walketh straightforwards.
14.21: For want of counsel purposes are frustrated; But in the multitude of counsellors they are established.
14.22: A man hath joy in the answer of his mouth; And a word in due season, how good is it!
14.23: The path of life goeth upward for the wise, that he may depart from the nether-world beneath.
14.28: The LORD is far from the wicked; But He heareth the prayer of the righteous.
14.29: The light of the eyes rejoiceth the heart; And a good report maketh the bones fat.
14.1: The tongue of the wise useth knowledge aright; But the mouth of fools poureth out foolishness.
14.0: A soft answer turneth away wrath; But a grievous word stirreth up anger.
14.3: A soothing tongue is a tree of life; But perverseness therein is a wound to the spirit.
14.2: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, Keeping watch upon the evil and the good.
14.5: In the house of the righteous is much treasure; But in the revenues of the wicked is trouble.
14.4: A fool despiseth his father’s correction; But he that regardeth reproof is prudent.
14.7: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD; But the prayer of the upright is His delight.
14.6: The lips of the wise disperse knowledge; But the heart of the foolish is not stedfast.
14.9: There is grievous correction for him that forsaketh the way; And he that hateth reproof shall die.
14.8: The way of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD; But He loveth him that followeth after righteousness.
14.11: A scorner loveth not to be reproved; He will not go unto the wise.
14.10: The nether-world and Destruction are before the LORD; How much more then the hearts of the children of men!
14.13: The heart of him that hath discernment seeketh knowledge; But the mouth of fools feedeth on folly.
14.12: A merry heart maketh a cheerful countenance; But by sorrow of heart the spirit is broken.
14.15: Better is little with the fear of the LORD, Than great treasure and turmoil therewith.
14.14: All the days of the poor are evil; But he that is of a merry heart hath a continual feast.
14.17: A wrathful man stirreth up discord; But he that is slow to anger appeaseth strife.
14.16: Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, Than a stalled ox and hatred therewith.
14.19: A wise son maketh a glad father; But a foolish man despiseth his mother.
14.18: The way of the sluggard is as though hedged by thorns; But the path of the upright is even.
14.31: He that refuseth correction despiseth his own soul; But he that hearkeneth to reproof getteth understanding.
14.30: The ear that hearkeneth to the reproof of life abideth among the wise.
14.32: The fear of the LORD is the instruction of wisdom; And before honour goeth humility.

17.20: Death and life are in the power of the tongue; And they that indulge it shall eat the fruit thereof.
17.21: Whoso findeth a wife findeth a great good, And obtaineth favour of the LORD.
17.22: The poor useth entreaties; But the rich answereth impudently.
17.23: There are friends that one hath to his own hurt; But there is a friend that sticketh closer than a brother.
17.1: A fool hath no delight in understanding, But only that his heart may lay itself bare.
17.0: He that separateth himself seeketh his own desire, And snarlest against all sound wisdom.
17.3: The words of a man’s mouth are as deep waters; A flowing brook, a fountain of wisdom.
17.2: When the wicked cometh, there cometh also contempt, And with ignominy reproach.
17.5: A fool’s lips enter into contention, And his mouth calleth for strokes.
17.4: It is not good to respect the person of the wicked, So as to turn aside the righteous in judgment.
17.7: The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels, And they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
17.6: A fool’s mouth is his ruin, And his lips are the snare of his soul.
17.9: The name of the LORD is a strong tower: The righteous runneth into it, and is set up on high.
17.8: Even one that is slack in his work Is brother to him that is a destroyer. .
17.11: Before destruction the heart of a man is haughty, And before honour goeth humility.
17.10: The rich man’s wealth is his strong city, And as a high wall in his own conceit.
17.13: The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; But a broken spirit who can bear?
17.12: He that giveth answer before he heareth, It is folly and confusion unto him.
17.15: A man’s gift maketh room for him, And bringeth him before great men.
17.14: The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; And the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
17.17: The lot causeth strife to cease, And parteth asunder the contentious.
17.16: He that pleadeth his cause first seemeth just; But his neighbour cometh and searcheth him out.
17.19: A man’s belly shall be filled with the fruit of his mouth; With the increase of his lips shall he be satisfied.
17.18: A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city; And their contentions are like the bars of a castle.

16.24: A foolish son is vexation to his father, And bitterness to her that bore him.
16.25: To punish also the righteous is not good, Nor to strike the noble for their uprightness.
16.26: He that spareth his words hath knowledge; And he that husbandeth his spirit is a man of discernment.
16.27: Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise; And he that shutteth his lips is esteemed as a man of understanding.
16.20: He that begetteth a fool doeth it to his sorrow; And the father of a churl hath no joy.
16.21: A merry heart is a good medicine; But a broken spirit drieth the bones.
16.22: A wicked man taketh a gift out of the bosom, To pervert the ways of justice.
16.23: Wisdom is before him that hath understanding; But the eyes of a fool are in the ends of the earth.
16.1: A servant that dealeth wisely shall have rule over a son that dealeth shamefully, And shall have part of the inheritance among the brethren.
16.0: Better is a dry morsel and quietness therewith, Than a house full of feasting with strife.
16.3: A evil-doer giveth heed to wicked lips; And a liar giveth ear to a mischievous tongue.
16.2: The refining pot is for silver, and the furnace for gold; But the LORD trieth the hearts. .
16.5: Children’s children are the crown of old men; And the glory of children are their fathers.
16.4: Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker; And he that is glad at calamity shall not be unpunished.
16.7: A gift is as a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it; Whithersoever he turneth, he prospereth.
16.6: Overbearing speech becometh not a churl; Much less do lying lips a prince.
16.9: A rebuke entereth deeper into a man of understanding Than a hundred stripes into a fool.
16.8: He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; But he that harpeth on a matter estrangeth a familiar friend.
16.11: Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a man, Rather than a fool in his folly.
16.10: A rebellious man seeketh only evil; Therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.
16.13: The beginning of strife is as when one letteth out water; Therefore leave off contention, before the quarrel break out.
16.12: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, Evil shall not depart from his house.
16.15: Wherefore is there a price in the hand of a fool To buy wisdom, seeing he hath no understanding?
16.14: He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the righteous, Even they both are an abomination to the LORD.
16.17: A man void of understanding is he that striketh hands, And becometh surety in the presence of his neighbour.
16.16: A friend loveth at all times, And a brother is born for adversity.
16.19: He that hath a forward heart findeth no good; And he that hath a perverse tongue falleth into evil.
16.18: He loveth transgression that loveth strife; He that exalteth his gate seeketh destruction.

19.24: It is a snare to a man rashly to say: ‘Holy’, and after vows to make inquiry.
19.25: A wise king sifteth the wicked, and turneth the wheel over them.
19.26: The spirit of man is the lamp of the LORD, searching all the inward parts.
19.27: Mercy and truth preserve the king; and his throne is upheld by mercy.
19.20: An estate may be gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.
19.21: Say not thou: ‘I will requite evil’; wait for the LORD, and He will save thee.
19.22: Divers weights are an abomination to the LORD; and a false balance is not good.
19.23: A man’s goings are of the LORD; how then can man look to his way?
19.28: The glory of young men is their strength; and the beauty of old men is the hoary head.
19.29: Sharp wounds cleanse away evil; So do stripes that reach the inward parts.
19.1: The terror of a king is as the roaring of a lion: He that provoketh him to anger forfeiteth his life.
19.0: Wine is a mocker, strong drink is riotous; and whosoever reeleth thereby is not wise.
19.3: The sluggard will not plow when winter setteth in; therefore he shall beg in harvest, and have nothing.
19.2: It is an honour for a man to keep aloof from strife; but every fool will be snarling.
19.5: Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness; but a faithful man who can find?
19.4: Counsel in the heart of man is like deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out. .
19.7: A king that sitteth on the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.
19.6: He that walketh in his integrity as a just man, happy are his children after him.
19.9: Divers weights, and divers measures, both of them alike are abomination to the LORD.
19.8: Who can say: ‘I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin’?
19.11: The hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the LORD hath made even both of them.
19.10: Even a child is known by his doings, whether his work be pure, and whether it be right.
19.13: ’It is bad, it is bad’, saith the buyer; but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.
19.12: Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes, and thou shalt have bread in plenty.
19.15: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger; and hold him in pledge that is surety for an alien woman.
19.14: There is gold, and a multitude of rubies; but the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
19.17: Every purpose is established by counsel; and with good advice carry on war.
19.16: Bread of falsehood is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
19.19: Whoso curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in the blackest darkness.
19.18: He that goeth about as a talebearer revealeth secrets; therefore meddle not with him that openeth wide his lips.

18.24: When thou smitest a scorner, the simple will become prudent; And when one that hath understanding is reproved, he will understand knowledge.
18.25: A son that dealeth shamefully and reproachfully Will despoil his father, and chase away his mother.
18.26: Cease, my son, to hear the instruction That causeth to err from the words of knowledge.
18.27: An ungodly witness mocketh at right; And the mouth of the wicked devoureth iniquity.
18.20: There are many devices in a man’s heart; But the counsel of the LORD, that shall stand.
18.21: The lust of a man is his shame; And a poor man is better than a liar.
18.22: The fear of the LORD tendeth to life; And he that hath it shall abide satisfied, He shall not be visited with evil.
18.23: The sluggard burieth his hand in the dish, And will not so much as bring it back to his mouth.
18.28: Judgments are prepared for scorners, And stripes for the back of fools.
18.1: Also, that the soul be without knowledge is not good; And he that hasteth with his feet sinneth.
18.0: Better is the poor that walketh in his integrity Than he that is perverse in his lips and a fool at the same time.
18.3: Wealth addeth many friends; But as for the poor, his friend separateth himself from him.
18.2: The foolishness of man perverteth his way; And his heart fretteth against the LORD.
18.5: Many will entreat the favour of the liberal man; And every man is a friend to him that giveth gifts.
18.4: A false witness shall not be unpunished; And he that breatheth forth lies shall not escape.
18.7: He that getteth wisdom loveth his own soul; He that keepeth understanding shall find good.
18.6: All the brethren of the poor do hate him; How much more do his friends go far from him! He that pursueth words, they turn against him.
18.9: Luxury is not seemly for a fool; Much less for a servant to have rule over princes.
18.8: A false witness shall not be unpunished; And he that breatheth forth lies shall perish.
18.11: The king’s wrath is as the roaring of a lion; But his favour is as dew upon the grass.
18.10: It is the discretion of a man to be slow to anger, And it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
18.13: House and riches are the inheritance of fathers; But a prudent wife is from the LORD.
18.12: A foolish son is the calamity of his father; And the contentions of a wife are a continual dropping.
18.15: He that keepeth the commandment keepeth his soul; But he that despiseth His ways shall die.
18.14: Slothfulness casteth into a deep sleep; And the idle soul shall suffer hunger.
18.17: Chasten thy son, for there is hope; But set not thy heart on his destruction. .
18.16: He that is gracious unto the poor lendeth unto the LORD; And his good deed will He repay unto him.
18.19: Hear counsel, and receive instruction, That thou mayest be wise in thy latter end.
18.18: A man of great wrath shall suffer punishment; For if thou interpose, thou wilt add thereto.

30.24: Strength and dignity are her clothing; And she laugheth at the time to come.
30.25: She openeth her mouth with wisdom; And the law of kindness is on her tongue.
30.26: She looketh well to the ways of her household, And eateth not the bread of idleness.
30.27: Her children rise up, and call her blessed; Her husband also, and he praiseth her:
30.20: She is not afraid of the snow for her household; For all her household are clothed with scarlet.
30.21: She maketh for herself coverlets; Her clothing is fine linen and purple.
30.22: Her husband is known in the gates, When he sitteth among the elders of the land.
30.23: She maketh linen garments and selleth them; And delivereth girdles unto the merchant.
30.28: ’Many daughters have done valiantly, But thou excellest them all.’
30.29: Grace is deceitful, and beauty is vain; But a woman that feareth the LORD, she shall be praised.
30.1: What, my son? and what, O son of my womb? And what, O son of my vows?
30.0: The words of king Lemuel; the burden wherewith his mother corrected him.
30.3: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine: Nor for princes to say: ‘Where is strong drink?’
30.2: Give not thy strength unto women, Nor thy ways to that which destroyeth kings.
30.5: Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, And wine unto the bitter in soul;
30.4: Lest they drink, and forget that which is decreed, And pervert the justice due to any that is afflicted.
30.7: Open thy mouth for the dumb, in the cause of all such as are appointed to destruction.
30.6: Let him drink, and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.
30.9: A woman of valour who can find? For her price is far above rubies.
30.8: Open thy mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.
30.11: She doeth him good and not evil all the days of her life.
30.10: The heart of her husband doth safely trust in her, and he hath no lack of gain.
30.13: She is like the merchant-ships; she bringeth her food from afar.
30.12: She seeketh wool and flax, and worketh willingly with her hands.
30.15: She considereth a field, and buyeth it; with the fruit of her hands she planteth a vineyard.
30.14: She riseth also while it is yet night,  and giveth food to her household, and a portion to her maidens.
30.17: She perceiveth that her merchandise is good; Her lamp goeth not out by night.
30.16: She girdeth her loins with strength, And maketh strong her arms.
30.19: She stretcheth out her hand to the poor; Yea, she reacheth forth her hands to the needy.
30.18: She layeth her hands to the distaff, And her hands hold the spindle.
30.30: Give her of the fruit of her hands; And let her works praise her in the gates.
